questions.text: Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses _____ as its second messenger.
questions.solution:
Vasopressin acts on the V2 receptor using cAMP as its second messenger.

Vasopressin acts on GPCR using different second messengers to accomplish its various actions as follows:

  • V1 receptor - vasoconstriction using phospholipase C as its second messenger
  • V2 receptor - reabsorption of water through aquaporin 2, using cAMP as its second messenger

Vasopressin has a maximum effect on the collecting ducts. It acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

Decreased ECF volume

Pain, emotions, stress, exercise

Nausea and vomiting

Standing

Angiotensin II

Clofibrate, carbamazepine

Decreased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Increased ECF volume

Alcohol

questions.text: Which of the following act as the second messenger for secretin?
questions.solution:
cAMP is the second messenger for the hormone secretin. It regulates fluid and electrolyte secretion and also mediates water and nutrient reabsorption.

questions.text: Which hormone mediates its action via cyclic GMP?
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide mediates its action via cyclic GMP or cGMP.

cGMP is the second messenger associated with smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) and NO (nitric oxide) are the only hormones that mediate their action via cGMP.

Note: Recent studies show that NO is a hormone. NO, which functions as a chemical messenger, has similar properties to hormones (which are known as the body's chemical messengers).

questions.text: What is the most abundant hormone produced by the pituitary gland?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) is the most abundant hormone produced by the pituitary gland.

It is produced by the acidophil cells or somatotropes of the anterior pituitary, which account for 50% of the anterior pituitary cell population.

Option A: Vasopressin is produced in the hypothalamus and only stored in the posterior pituitary.

Option C: Corticotrophs account for 10% of the anterior pituitary cell population.

Option D: Thyrotrophs account for 5% of the anterior pituitary cell population.

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: Insulin acts on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Insulin acts on the tyrosine kinase receptor, a cell-surface receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the twin hormone of prolactin?
questions.solution:
GH and prolactin are called twin hormones as both are secreted by the acidophil cells of the anterior pituitary. They act on cytokine receptors and show JAK-STAT activity.

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is an amino acid derivative?
questions.solution:
The thyroid hormone is synthesized from tyrosine residues and thus is an amino acid derivative.

Insulin, activin and parathyroid hormone are large protein hormones.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones According to their Chemical Structure

Proteins and polypeptide hormones

  • Large proteins (> 50 amino acids)
    • Anterior pituitary hormones: FSH, LH, GH, Prolactin
    • Parathyroid hormone
    • Insulin
  • Small peptides (< 50 amino acids)
    • Posterior pituitary hormones: Oxytocin, ADH
    • ACTH
    • Glucagon

Steroid hormones

  • Cortisol and aldosterone
  • Estrogen and progesterone
  • Testosterone
  • DHEA

Derivatives of a specific amino acid

  • Tyrosine
    • Thyroid hormones
    • Catecholamines
  • Tryptophan
    • Serotonin (5-HT)
    • Melatonin
  • Arginine
    • Nitric oxide

questions.text: Which of the following chemical molecules is not a steroid hormones?
questions.solution:
Inhibin is a large protein hormone, not a steroid hormone.

All adrenocortical and reproductive hormones are steroid hormones synthesized from cholesterol precursors except activin and inhibin.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones According to their Chemical Structure

questions.text: Which class of hormones does insulin belong to?
questions.solution:
Insulin is classified as a large protein hormone (>50 amino acid residues) as it is composed of 51 amino acids. 

Protein and polypeptide hormones are classified as small peptides (< 50 amino acid residues) and large proteins. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones According to their Chemical Structure

questions.text: The action of cAMP is mediated by _____
questions.solution:
The action of cAMP is mediated by protein kinases.

cAMP is a second messenger molecule associated with electrolyte secretion and water and nutrient reabsorption. It is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase but it mediates its actions via protein kinases.

Related Pearl: Membrane receptors and their mechanisms

1. G protein coupled receptor(GPCR)

   Effect 2nd messenger  Action
Gs Activates adenylate cyclase Stimulation of cAMP production Activates protein kinase A
Gi Inhibits adenylate cyclase Inhibition of cAMP production -
Gq Activates phospholipase C Liberate DAG and IP3 which mobilize Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum Activates protein kinase C


2. Guanylyl cyclase receptor

Effector 2nd messenger
Guanylyl cyclase Stimulation of cGMP production


3. Receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
Tyrosine kinase MAP kinase


4. Cytokine receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
JAK, tyrosine kinase STAT, MAP kinase


5. Serine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
Serine kinase Smads

questions.solution:
cAMP is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase, but it mediates its actions via protein kinases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not activated by the binding of epinephrine to its receptor?
questions.solution:
The binding of epinephrine to its various receptors results in the activation of different types of G-protein subunits, namely Gq, Gi, and Gs.

All catecholamines act via G protein-coupled receptors. This stimulates cAMP production and signaling via protein kinases.

questions.text: The enzyme kinase adds ______ to proteins.
questions.solution:
Kinases are a subclass of transferases that catalyze the transfer of a phosphate group from a donor to an acceptor protein. They are associated with the regulation of many essential cellular processes.

Related Pearl: Membrane receptors and their mechanisms
